abstract.shortdesc: Adding a VSA node allows you to add additional capacity.
abstract.p: You may have a need to add a VSA node for additional storage capacity or another purpose and these steps will help you achieve this.

body.p: The process for adding additional VSA nodes to your cloud environment involves two major tasks:

ul.li: Adding the VSA node(s) to your input model
Updating your VSA management group and cluster to add the additional node(s)

body.p: Once you have completed these two tasks, you should add those new hosts to your monitoring checks following the directions in How to add an additional VSA node to your monitoring checks.

section.title: Prerequisites
section.p: You should have one or more baremetal servers that meet the minimum hardware requirements for a VSA node which are detailed in the Hardware Support Matrix.

section.title: Notes
section.p: When adding additional VSA nodes you should consider the high availability (HA) implications to this action. Your VSA nodes are made highly available via the server-group and cluster options. For example, if you had an existing cluster of 3 VSA nodes and you dispersed them across three server-groups using RACK1, RACK2, and RACK3 and you wanted to additional capacity you may want to consider adding another cluster of 3 VSA nodes to maintain high availability. If you want to add an additional 1-2 VSA nodes per RACK then that is also possible but you would lose the HA aspect of the server-group.
The recommended maximum number of VSA nodes per cluster is 16 before you need to create additional clusters.

section.title: How to add an additional VSA node to your input model and deploy it
section.p: Follow these steps to add additional VSA nodes to your cloud environment.

ol.li: Log in to your lifecycle manager.
Checkout the site branch of your local git so you can begin to make the necessary edits: cd ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data git checkout site

Edit your ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/servers.yml file to include the details about your new VSA node(s), ensuring you take into account the notes at the top of this page concerning HA.
For example, if you already had a cluster of three VSA nodes and needed to add a fourth one you would add your details to the bottom of the file in this format:# VSA Storage Nodes
- id: vsa4 ip-addr: 10.13.111.148 role: VSA-ROLE server-group: RACK1 nic-mapping: HP-DL360-4PORT mac-addr: f0:92:1c:05:f5:78 ilo-ip: 192.168.9.4 ilo-password: password ilo-user: admin
You can find detailed descriptions of these fields here.You will need to verify that the ip-addr value you choose for this node does not conflict with any other IP address in your cloud environment. You can confirm this by checking the ~/helion/my_cloud/info/address_info.yml file on your lifecycle manager.

In your ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/control_plane.yml file you will need to check the values for member-count, min-count, and max-count, if you specified them, to ensure that they match up with your new total node count.
For example, if you had previously specified member-count: 3 and are adding a fourth VSA node, you will need to change that value to member-count: 4.
See Input Model - Control Plane for more details.
Commit your configuration to the local git repo, as follows: git commit -a -m "Adding additional VSA node"
Run the configuration processor: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
Update your deployment directory: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml
Add the new node into Cobbler: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost cobbler-deploy.yml

Then you can image the node: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost bm-reimage.yml -e nodelist=<node name>If you don't know the <node name> already, you can get it by using sudo cobbler system list
Before proceeding, you may want to take a look at ~/helion/my_cloud/info/server_info.yml to see if the assignment of the node you have added is what you expect. It may not be, as nodes will not be numbered consecutively if any have previously been removed. This is to prevent loss of data; the configuration processor retains data about removed nodes and keeps their ID numbers from being reallocated. See the Persisted Server Allocations section in Input Model for information on how this works.

Complete the deployment of your new node with this playbook, ensuring you use the --limit option. With the --limit switch you will need to specify your first controller node (which may be your lifecycle manager) if you are adding VSA nodes to your environment for the first time. If you added a VSA cluster during your initial cloud deploy then you only need to specify your new VSA nodes and can leave the controller node out. cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts site.yml --tags "generate_hosts_file" ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts site.yml --limit <hostname_vsa_node,hostname_first_controller>If you don't know the <hostname> already, you can get it by looking in the ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible/host_vars directory.

section.title: How to add an additional VSA node to your management group and cluster
section.p: You can add additional VSA node(s) in an automated process using the provided Ansible playbooks only if you used this method initially to create the cluster. If you used the HPE StoreVirtual Centralized Management Console (CMC) GUI to create the cluster, you must continue to use the CMC utility to add new node(s) and manage your cluster.

If you initially created your VSA cluster using Ansible (using the instructions, you can add nodes to that cluster using the same playbook. Using this playbook to perform cluster operations is highly recommended.

ol.li: Log in to the lifecycle manager.
Run the following playbook, which will update both your management group and your cluster: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible/ ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts vsalm-configure-cluster.yml
When prompted, enter an administrative user name and password you will use to administer your cluster via the CMC utility, should it be needed in the future.
Confirm in the output of the playbook that your new node is added.

You can view the added node to the cluster in CMC GUI as follows:
Launch the CMC utility. See Launching the CMC utility GUI for more details.
Find the VSA system.
View the added node in the cluster.

section.p: Show | Hide Using the CMC Utility

ol.li: On your lifecycle manager, collect the IP addresses of the VSA virtual machines that you added from the ~/scratch/ansible/next/my_cloud/stage/info/net_info.yml file. This file is generated as part of output of the configuration processor during installation. You will need this IP address in the next steps.
Launch the CMC utility. You will likely want to use the same method you used when you did your initial VSA cluster configuration. See Launching the CMC utility GUI for more details.
In the CMC GUI, click the Find menu and then select the Find Systems options.

Click the Add button which will open the Enter IP Address dialogue box where you can enter the IP address of the VSA node(s) that you are adding. These will be the same IP addresses you noted in step 1 from your ~/scratch/ansible/next/my_cloud/stage/info/net_info.yml file.
Once you have all of your VSA nodes entered, click the Close button.
Next, click the Tasks menu and then navigate to the System submenu and select the Add to Existing Management Group option.
In the Management Group wizard, select your new VSA node and then press Continue.
Select your Group Name from the drop down box and then press Add to continue.
The CMC utility will then add your new VSA node to the management group. Once it has completed you will see the Status change to Storage System Normal.

Add the VSA node to an existing cluster.
Right click the newly added VSA node and select Add to Existing Cluster:
Select your cluster from the drop down box. Select the storage system to add to the cluster and then click OK:
You can then mouse over your VSA node to see the Storage System get successfully added to the cluster:
